data.title: The making of Alan Partridge: from The Day Today to comedy icon
data.meta_description: In documentary Alan Partridge: Why, When, Where, How and Whom? Steve Coogan admits to difficulties during the character's creation.
data.text:
Twenty years on from the first series of I’m Alan Partridge, the Norwich based comedic creation is returning to the BBC.

Prefacing Partridge’s return is the documentary ‘Alan Partridge: Why, When, Where, How and Whom?’, airing tonight (27 December) and featuring cast and crew members ruminating over the character’s creation.

Despite Partridge’s near-universal popularity (aside from the late Tony Hayers), it’s surprising to learn that Steve Coogan and his fellow writers had major doubts about the Norfolk presenter’s longevity.

I’m Alan Partridge at 20: what it was like to play Michael the Geordie

Pitching Partridge

When Coogan first pitched his character of a sports presenter at comedy radio show On The Hour, he quickly had his colleagues in raptures.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Nim8pj8CWqw

Co-creator Armando Ianucci explains the origins of the character’s name:

“The moment he started speaking everyone else started laughing and somebody said ‘he’s a Partridge, he’s Mr Partridge’ and somebody else said ‘and he’s Alan’.”

He was an instant hit with his fellow comedians.

Coogan recalls how screenwriter Patrick Marber predicted Partridge’s success during the character’s development: “This character is going to change your life – people are going to be shouting “aha!” at you from across the street.”

Despite this vote of confidence, Coogan had his doubts. Speaking candidly, he says: “I remember thinking this character can’t sustain half an hour.”

If it weren’t for the encouragement of Marber, Coogan may have packed in Partridge before he found a wider audience.

25 of the most textbook Alan Partridge quotes

Scepticism over a sitcom

Alan Partridge quickly became a hit with audiences despite Coogan’s doubts, through his chat show Knowing Me, Knowing You, after a stint on The Day Today.

Coogan notes that the mock chat show was the launchpad for his character.

“Knowing Me Knowing you: that’s what really put Alan on the map.”

With this confidence, Ianucci and Coogan began plotting Partridge’s move to a sitcom.

The script was initally pitched to Marber, who admits to scepticism.

“When Armando and Steve showed me the first script they had, charmingly seeking my approval, I didn’t give it.”

Once again, Partridge’s future was in doubt.

Coogan notes that there was a fear of “losing Alan’s DNA”, which had been painstakingly built up over the past few years.

I’m Alan Partridge: checking into the Linton Travel Tavern

However, Marber’s fears proved to be unfounded as Coogan and Ianucci pushed on with the creation of the sitcom, which would become known as ‘I’m Alan Partridge’.

“I should have had the sense to think about what it would be like when it was shot by Armando and played by Steve,” admits Marber.

Twenty years on from the debut of I’m Alan Partridge, the show remains as popular now, its best scenes and lines enjoying a weird kind of immortality on social media.

The desperate, despicable, but strangely lovable character displayed hilariously awkward tendencies unseen by audiences before.

The genius of the character was developed by Coogan, Ianucci and writer Peter Baynham, who would film themselves pitching ideas and bouncing ideas off each other.

Coogan notes that the hit rate of these sessions was typically “10 per cent.”

Ianucci describes how the trio would “muck about a bit”, while Peter recalls that the three of them would pitch in Partridge’s voice, resulting in a surreal but hilarious situation.

‘Give me another series, you s**t’

Following the popularity of the instantly iconic first series, a second quickly followed.

Following a mental breakdown, Alan stops living full time in a hotel and moves into a caravan – this was designed to retain a claustrophobic style.

Coogan, however, says he regrets this move.

“In retrospect we probably should have done two series in the hotel, but it was just this sort of fear of getting lazy.”

Coogan believes that the second series was far darker than the debut outing.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uIqa11NCbmA

“Series two is quite dark I think, there’s not much hope in it,” he says.

“The spike[scene] was a real low point. We were thinking what would be literally and metaphorically painful for Alan.”

While the scene proved to be comedy gold, Ianucci admits that things got “a little bit tense” during filming.

Coogan notes that he was becoming overwhelmed with the character and that after a second season “we had to stop it”.

Jet from Gladiators on her 90s fame – and Alan Partridge

What would Alan do?

As Coogan stepped away from Partridge he admits to initial “wildernessy” years in which he tried to forge a different comedy career path.

Despite stepping away from the character, Partridge remained close to his heart.

“I started thinking, what would Alan do in these moments?”

In 2010, eight years after the finale of I’m Alan Partridge, Coogan made the decision to breathe life back into Alan Partridge, with the low-key web-series Mid Morning Matters, and three years later came the film Alpha Papa.

With the imminent arrival of a new chat show, audiences will soon be introduced to the next chapter in the iconic character’s life.

Actress Felicity Montagu, who played Lynn in I’m Alan Partridge, insists that audiences “will see him [Alan] growing old – definitely.”

And Coogan, despite his initial scepticism over the character’s potential, admits that he would be devastated if he ever said farewell to Partridge for good.

“If I had to say goodbye to Alan forever I would be very upset. He’s my friend.”

Alan Partridge: Why, When, Where, How and Whom? is on tonight (27 December) at 9pm on BBC Two.
